title: What was one reason for the pressure to conform in the 1950s? - Quora

response.answer_text: In general, people conform because their is an imperative to succeed that depends on it. In the United States for example, if you worked for a company, you conformed to the corporate dress code because otherwise you would get fired. However, American culture celebrates the ‘rugged individual’ and ‘self made person’ and newness, so often non-conformity is looked on positively because they were otherwise successful. America doesn’t celebrate conformity as a default good, so if you mostly followed common societal norms, you didn’t feel any pressure. Compare that with Japan where conformity is seen as a positive in itself, and stepping outside of the norm in even small ways can be viewed as disruptive. For example, an in-law of mine was singled out in a company in the late 1980s as being somewhat disruptive because he grew a mustache.
Shrea, I grew up in the 50's and never felt a pressure to conform to anything. Do you have specifics that would help explain your question? Mick
WW2 training and trauma followed by Post WW2 depression, personal not financial. For more insight I suggest “The Majestic” by Jim Carrey.
